Gazes around her as if discovering something new often has an expression of eager surprise, as if seeing t people, places for the first time ever. She seems uncomfortable in the clothes she is wearing. At is an old-fashioned suitcase. A younger woman (LEA, early 30s) appears behind Juliette. a meter away. Juliette hasn’t noticed her. Clearly deeply moved, Léa qu observes her for a few seconds. Then, sensing a presence, Juliette looks round. Léa leans forward and hugs her tight before Juliette has react. Juliette is slightly taken aback. She doesn’t return the hug at first. Then awkwardly puts round Léa. 2. INT. LEA’S CAR - DAY Léa is driving. Next to her, Juliette tugs at the sleeves of her sweater.
Is it too big?
No.
I like that sweater. The skirt, too. I often wear them. Juliette doesn’t reply.

I thought it would be better to wait until you arrived to go shopping for clothes. Léa glances at Juliette. Beat. There’s something out of place about Juliette. She even s in the car seat, as if unused to it.
Did you have a good trip?
I don’t like flying. Léa glances at her again.
Have you lived here long?

Ten years. I finished my PhD here, met Luc, got married, was offered the job... The usual stuff. Juliette is silent. The CAMERA lingers on her face. 3. INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Léa shows Juliette into the house.

Welcome to our kingdom! The kitchen’s over there with the living room opposite, our home offices and a library at the far end. Upstairs, there’s just bedrooms. Do you want to see yours? Juliette replies by a slight nod and the flicker of a smi Léa leads the way up the stairs. On the first landing, she shows Juliette into a room.
Will it be okay?
Fine.

That little door leads to your private bathroom. (glances at her watch) Yikes, I have to pick up the girls! I’1l be back in half an hour. Will you be okay on your own? Juliette nods. Léa hurries out. On the landing, she stops in her tracks. Slowly retraces her step, looks at Juliette and says in a tone:
I’m glad you’re here. Léa gives Juliette a kiss on the cheek and goes. Juliette is expressionless. OS, feet dashing down the stairs. The jangle of keys.

Take a look round the house, if you want ! The front door thunks closed. Juliette hasn’t moved an inch. She remains motionless like that for a long Moment. 4. INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY MONTAGE of Juliette’s tour of the house. In the living room, she strokes a cat dozing on a chair. In a study, she runs her hand over the back of a couch. G framed photos. In the kitchen, she pours herself a glass of water. Drink leaning back against the fridge. Upstairs, Juliette opens a door. A child’s bedroom. She c door hurriedly. She opens another door. A library full of books. With a s and two chairs. Sitting in one of the chairs, an elderly reading.
I’m sorry, I... I didn’t think anyone was home. The old man looks up without a word and smiles at her.
I... My name’s Juliette. I’m Léa’s sister. Still not a word. Just a kindly smile.

Like I said, I’m very sorry. Smiling, the old man goes back to his book, as if indiffe her presence. 5. EXT/INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Léa closes the back door of the car. She has a two-year-o (EMELIA) in her arms. Another little girl, (CLELIS, known as Little Lili) waits sidewalk. She looks 8-9 years old. Both girls are Asian.
Lili, open the gate, will you? You know it’s hard when I’m carrying Emelia. They go through the gate into the small front garden.
Is Auntie Juliette going to stay with us forever?
No, sweetheart, just some time. Be nice to her, okay? She’s tired. Don’t pester her. They enter the house.
Juliette? It’s us! Juliette comes down the stairs. The kids gaze up at her. As soon as she reaches the bottom step, Lili rushes over.

Hello, Auntie! Juliette seems quite distant, or maybe just ill at ease. Lili stands on tiptoes to give her a kiss. Juliette hesitates fractionally before giving her a kiss Emelia gurgles the word “Auntie” repeatedly.
These are my two princesses, Clélis - but everybody calls her Little Lili - and little miss Emelia. Give Juliette a nice smile, sweety!
Auntie, come and see my bedroom!
Don’t start! Go straight into the kitchen. There’s milk and biscuits on the table. Chop, chop. The two girls run off into the kitchen.
Did you look round the house?
Yes, I... I went into the library. There was an old man...
Of course, silly me, I should have warned you. That’s Luc’s father.
(yells) Papy Paul! His brain’s gone all mushy and he lost his tongue!
Lili! He had a bad stroke three years ago. He hasn’t spoken a word since. He  spends all day reading. You’1l see, he’s a lovely man.

Dinner time. The whole family is round the table: Léa, th girls, Juliette, Papy Paul - smiling dumbly - and Luc, Lé husband, also in his early-mid 30s. The two young girls are very excited. Léa makes a big effort to seem relaxed. Juliette still seems a little strange, as if everything i her. And Luc just seems a bit uptight. Luc Have you ever been to the Lorraine region before?
No, this is the first time. Luc Everybody thinks it’s just like being in Germany, that it’s freezing cold all the time...
It is! Luc Not all the time.
Just eat your dinner!
Were you born here? Luc Yes, but my Dad comes from Poland. He arrived after the war. Isn’t that right, Dad? The old man merely smiles a little more insistently than
Luc’s Mum was Russian. He married a girl who’s half-French, half-English. And our two daughters are Viet. It’s all the colors of Benetton in this house.
You’ve lost your accent, Mummy, but Auntie Juliette still has one.
Well, she grew up in England. Luc Anybody see the water jug?

Katrina broke it and I haven’t had time to buy another. (to Juliette) Katrina’s the cleaner. She comes every Thursday. Hide anything fragile. She’s always breaking things. That’s why we call her Katrina. Because she leaves a trail of devastation behind her! Her real name’s Marie-Paule.
(to Luc) Léa said you do research at the university?
(jokily) You two sound like we’re at a party full of strangers.
Daddy’s a lexicolographer. Luc Lexicographer’s good enough for me. Our unit is working on an interactive, intuitive dictionary that can be reactivated in real time.

It’s you guys that need to reactivate. In seven years, they’ve only got to ‘C’. Even the Académie Frangaise goes faster than that. Luc There’s no comparison. That reminds me, there was a message on the machine from one of your students, a guy called Bamaké or Bakamé, something like that. A problem with his marks, I think.
Bamakalé? I don’t believe it! He won’t give up.
Why didn’t we ever meet you before, Auntie? Everyone falls silent. Juliette doesn’t know what to say. Luc glances anxiously The two girls don’t seem to notice. Papy Paul keeps on ea smiling away.
I was... away. For a very long time. Léa changes the subject. A little too quickly. She hands Juliette a dish.
Do you want some more?
No, thanks.
Don’t you like it?
It’s very good, but...

Where were you away? Luc (snaps) Is this some kind of interrogation! Leave your aunt in peace! Eat! 7. INT. LEA & LUC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Léa and Luc are ready for bed. Luc How long does she plan on staying?
How should I know? As long as she needs. A few weeks, a few months... Is it a problem? Luc To be honest, yes. Okay, she’s your sister, but...
But what? Luc You heard Lili. She wanted to know.
So? Luc Her being “away” won’t work for long.
It’1l work as long as it works, we’1l see. Luc “We’1l see! We’ll see!” You make me laugh. What are you going to say to her? The truth?

Luc, don’t give me a hard time. This is our first evening. I’ve just got my sister back. I don’t know if you realize what that means. I’ve just got her back. Luc You hardly know her. Just because you went to see her a couple of times for a few hours in the last few months doesn’t... You were only a teenager when she -

Be quiet! Luc Okay, I’1l be quiet. Quiet as a mouse. (beat ) But think of us a little, too. 8. INT. JULIETTE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Juliette stands by the window. We can vaguely make out th below. Juliette is still wearing Léa’s clothes Léa. She goes ove bed. Sits on the edge, as if she plans to spend the whole like that.

It’s total, happy, bubbly chaos in the kitchen. The girls are finishing their breakfast. Léa is a whirl o activity. Still in his pyjamas, Papy Paul slurps coffee from a bowl as_ always. Juliette observes the scene, leaning against the wall wit tea in one hand. 10
C’mon, kids! Chop, chop, we’re gonna be late!
Aren’t we always?
Emelia, what are you doing? What are you doing? I don’t believe it! Emelia has smeared yoghurt all over her dress.
I’1l have to change your dress now. Lili, finish up quickly. Léa dashes out with Emelia in her arms. Papy Paul leaves also. Juliette and Little Lili are alone.
Don’t you eat breakfast?
It depends.
I’m never hungry in the morning. Ever since I was a little girl. Mummy gets so angry! Did you ever see me when I was little, when Mummy and Daddy brought me back from Vietnam?
Sure.
I don’t believe you. Your nose is getting longer. (beat ) Daddy! Luc has just entered. Little Lili throws her arms round h Luc (awkwardly) Morning, Juliette. Did you sleep well?
Léa and Little Lili get out of the car and join the flow and children. Léa turns and leans towards the passenger side window.
You’re not coming? 11
I’1l1 wait here.
‘Bye, Auntie! Juliette looks overwhelmed by it all. She doesn’t answer. Little Lili and Léa walk toward the gates.
I put some more canteen tickets in your bag.
I noticed.
Your gym stuff is in there, too. Try not to lose anything this time.
Mummy?
What?
Auntie’s a bit weird, isn’t she?
What makes you say that?
I don’t know. She doesn’t say much.
Give her time to adapt, eh? Go on, go! A kiss and Little Lili walks into school.

Ask Madame Rouyer if she found your pink beret! 11, INT. LEA’S CAR - DAY Juliette is in the passenger seat. Léa’s face looms up at the window. Juliette stares straight ahead, breathing heavily. Léa walks round and gets in behind the wheel.
Are you okay? Juliette nods several times, her breath rasping slightly. 12
Sure?
Yes. Léa pulls out and drives in silence for a moment. Beat. Juliette shrugs.
The police station is close to the university. I’m teaching for two hours, but we can meet up after, if you want? There’s a nice café just opposite the campus gates.
Okay.
You know what they want to see you for?
I have to sign in at regular times.
Didn’t you ever see anyone? I mean, did anyone come to see you?
The visitors.
(beat ) Do you hate me?
What for?
For never coming to see you.
I wrote at first.
I never received any letters.
One evening, Dad saw me. Mummy and him gave me a real roasting. They banned me from writing. They said you... you 13  didn’t exist. I was a kid then you know.
I meant to tell you...
What?
It was the social services who came up with the idea to call you just before I got out, not me.
I’m glad they did. Beat.
I’m glad they did.
Juliette sits on a bench with an OLD LADY beside her. The old lady glances at Juliette. Smiles. Juliette smiles Beat. The old lady glances at her again.
Are you reporting a crime, too?
No. Just then, an INSPECTOR appears. Plain clothes, same age Juliette.
Juliette Fontaine?
Yes.

Follow me, please. 13. INT. INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Juliette sits opposite the Inspector He flicks through a file, pores over a couple of pages, g few pages and re-reads, frowning, but not hostile or judg friendly almost. He closes the file.
14  I see you’re a doctor.
Was. I was struck off the medical register.

Makes no difference. Once a doctor always a doctor. It’s like me. I’11 always be a cop. (suddenly) You have a pretty name. I don’t like my name, but Fontaine is very pretty. It brings to mind gurgling water streams, rivers... The Orinoco. You know the Orinoco? No? He uses his pen to point to a poster on the wall behind h shows a broad swathe of an unidentifiable river.

There’1l1 be no more fountains soon. Municipalities are closing them down - even in tiny villages. They’re filled with earth and made into flower beds. Stupid geraniums, usually. (switches topic again) I won’t hassle you. The law says we have to see each other, so we see each other, but I won’t give you any bother. Do you have a job?
Not yet.
A place to stay.
With my sister.
That’s nice. Family’s important. You’re lucky. I live alone. Divorced. Small apartment. Small bed. Anyway, you don’t want to hear all that. He gets up, goes to the door.
See you in two weeks?
Goodbye.
Goodbye. 15

Léa walks down a hallway. Groups of students hang out, sh breeze. Léa nods to a colleague going the other way. She enters t room, checks through the mail in her box, throws some stu She opens and scans one letter. Then another that makes her roll her eyes.
Not him again! He’s a real pain! Another colleague (MICHEL) approaches and whispers into L
One of your many lovers writing to you? Léa doesn’t look round, just keeps reading.
If only! Bamakalé!
Ah ha! Prosper Napoleon Bamakalé, descendant of ancient Togolese royalty, son of a prince of royal blood, repeating his first year for the third time.
I’m getting fond of him, actually. I keep telling him it’s not a mistake, but he doesn’t get it.
Tell me about it! I had him all last year. Are you off?
I’m done for the day.
I’11 walk you to your car. They step outside without a break in their conver sation.
Have you finished marking your mid - terms?
Almost. I have ten or so left to do.
16  Lucky you! I haven’t even started. Every time I look at the pile on my desk, I feel so exhausted.
Get a move on though, the Dean wants all the marks in by the 18".
The Dean! (changes subject) What did you decide for that conference I told you about?
We’1l see. Léa sees Juliette waiting by the car.
You’re already here? I thought we were meeting in the café.
It didn’t take very long.
Michel, this is Juliette, my sister. Juliette, this is Michel, a colleague.
Hello... (to Léa) You never told me you had a sister and a very pretty one at that.
Don’t listen to him. Michel’s a specialist on love letters from the 16" century to the present day. And it rubs off on him. (to Michel) Friday of next week, are you free?
why?
Dinner at our house, with Samir and Kaisha.
I should be able to make it. Can I let you know next week?
17  Sure. Don’t forget your marking.
Goodbye, Juliette.
Goodbye.
C’mon, let’s go shopping.
Juliette and Léa are sitting at a table with a cup of tea a plate of cakes. On the chair next to them and at their feet are shopping various stores.
Good?
(nods) You remember Bouchard’s in Rouen?
No.
It was a bit like this. I used to take you there on a Wednesday after your ballet lesson.
With Old Mother Stabush?
Fat Old Mother Stabush!
She couldn’t even do points anymore. I remember she had a moustache, too. We were all scared of her.
I was at uni and I always picked you up and took you to Bouchard’s. You had a cream puff every time.
(tremulously) I don’t remember.
18  You were only seven or eight. There were always stacks of old ladies in there...
(like it’s a real drama) Why don’t I remember?
You sat there so proud. A proper little lady with your cream cake.
(tears up) I don’t even remember it. Juliette suddenly realizes that Léa is distraught.
Don’t worry, you were only little. 16. INT. LITTLE LILI’S BEDROOM - EVENING The door opens. Little Lili and Juliette enter the bedroom, followed by E
(to Emelia) No, you’re not coming in! Out! It’s my room! You can show her yours later. (closes the door) Kid sisters are so annoying! Was Mummy like that when she was little?
She wasn’t too bad.
Is she your real sister?
Yes.
You’re Granny Lizbeth’s daughter, too?
That’s right.
Okay, this is the doll graveyard. She opens a suitcase filled with a dozen dolls.

I don’t like dolls, so when someone gives me one, I bury it in here right 19  away. That’s my computer. I watch DVDs on it mostly and type up my schoolwork. That’s what I made for Mother’s Day, but Katrina broke it. She says it wasn’t her, but she’s a liar! Those are my books...
Dinner time!
Do you read a lot? Juliette runs her fingers along the spines of the books. over one she apparently remembers from her childhood, cal Little Ladies.
Less than Papy Paul, but quite a lot yes. This is my secret diary - well, it’s not so secret seeing as I leave it out and everybody can read it. I write poems in it. Do you want me to read you one?
(recoils) No.
Please, Auntie! Just a little one.
(snaps) No. I said no! Little Lili looks at her in amazement. Juliette scurries out of the room.
Juliette is with a plump, smiling young woman ( the SOCIA They each sit on a couch facing each other across a coffe
You’re lucky to have your sister, her family and a home.
So I’ve been told.
It’s true, though. Most people, when they get out, don’t know where to go. Nobody wants them. Their spouses almost always file for divorce. 20
I got that out of the way before I went in.
Yes, it’s in your file. Right, well, the courses you did at Centrale will be very useful. People always need secretaries. Are your IT skills up to speed?
I did all the updates whenever I got the chance.

That’s good. I got you an interview at this company... (hands Juliette a card) They’re looking for someone. You have an appointment with a Monsieur Dupuis. We’1l be meeting regularly, but if you have any questions or anything, don’t hesitate to call me at the office...
Right.

I have to go now. You have people you can talk to, and there’s only two of us in the department. (beat ) I like the house. They get up. Juliette walks her to the door. They say goo Outside, Léa parks her car and gets out. She meets the So Worker by the gate. They nod. Léa enters.
Was that the social worker?
Yes.
She seems sweet enough.
People whose role is to rummage through your life often seem sweet enough. Léa glances curiously at her sister. Puts her bag down. T 21

I guess you’re right. We had that, too - Luc and me - when we adopted. Visits for this, visits for that, social workers, shrinks, and even an idiot doctor who had Luc walking up and down in his underpants in his office with his arms stretched out! I thought Luc was going to strangle him. He really resented all the questions and prying... Tea?
Léa is making tea. Juliette stands close by.

It took nearly two years for Little Lili and a bit less for Emelia. The first time we spent three months in Vietnam. We fell in love with the place and would have happily stayed longer. We had Little Lili with us almost the whole time, at the hotel, but the bureaucracy and all the formalities took forever.
Léa?
Yes, Marie-Paule?
Shall I do the crystal, too?
No, don’t worry, leave it! I’1l do it! Do the cupboard doors, will you?
How old was Little Lili?
Two. But she looked half that.
You met her mother?

No. But I have her address if ever she wants to contact her. That was very important for us. We didn’t want her to run into a brick wall later if she tried to find her. Emelia, on the other hand... Well, we got absolutely no information. She’1l never know... 22
How old was she?
She was tiny! Barely three weeks old. Beat.
Was it Luc or you who couldn’t have kids?
Neither of us. We’re both fertile. (beat ) I didn’t want a child of my own.
Because of me? No answer.
Because of what I did? Beat.
I never tried to work out why. 19. INT. DUPUIS’ OFFICE - DAY MONSIEUR DUPUIS, early 50s, smug, sits behind his desk, t the phone. Juliette sits opposite him.
Yes, well... So what?... That’s not my problem. We pay you to deliver our order, so you deliver it, period! Goodbye! He hangs up. Gazes at Juliette.
Right, where were we... I won’t beat around the bush. I’m not a charity. I want skilled, hard-working staff. The rest is not my problem. Mrs... what’s her name again? Balboukian?
That’s right.
. said that you are up to speed with Excel, DTP and the whole shebang. Right? 23
I passed all the tests.
And you speak English?
And Spanish.
I don’t give a shit about Spanish but we have a lot of clients across the Channel. There’s stacks of stuff that needs translating... How long were you in jail?
Fifteen years.
(whistles) Jeez! You knock off the President or something? No answer.
What did you do? Still no answer.
I want to know. What did you do to get so long? Kill someone? Did you?
Yes.
Who? Your husband? Lover? Another woman? No answer.
I’m talking to you. Who did you kill?
My son. My six-year-old son. The blood seeps out of Dupuis’ face. He drops the pencil he was fiddling with and pushes back chair. Beat. He gets slowly to his feet.
24  (rasps) Get out! Get the hell out of my office!

Juliette is in a small bar, near the window, watching eve outside and in. At the bar a GUY, who’s good-looking and knows it, talks with another guy and the waitress. Nothing of their conversation filters over, except the oc burst of laughter. Juliette glances over a couple of times, when they laugh particularly loudly. Eventually, the guy notices Juliette, and watches her whi continuing his conversation with the others. After a while, he comes over. Without asking, he takes a Juliette’s table.
You want my photo? Juliette doesn’t answer.
Have we met?
I don’t think so.
Why were you staring at me then? what do you want?
Nothing. I wasn’t staring at you.
Bullshit! You keep eying me up. You looking for a man? Juliette smiles, amused by his question. Then, she eyes him up and down.
Juliette lies pensively in bed, the sheets pulled up to h The guy comes out of the bathroom and finishes dressing.
Was it good? Juliette gazes at him before answering.
No. Not at all. But it’s okay. 25  The guy looks furious. He mumbles something, grabs his jacket and storms out. The camera holds on Juliette, who hasn’t moved an inch.
Léa and Juliette walk side by side, chatting. The two little girls run ahead. Wide shot. Then the CAMERA is right behind them. The children are already standing at some animal cages.
Auntie, look! They’re monkeys. Sometimes they spit at people. They all stop by the monkey cages. Little Lili and Emelia pulls faces.
It’s not fair locking them up. They haven’t done anything. Prisons are for bad people, not animals? Isn’t that so, Mummy? Eh, Auntie? Léa grabs Little Lili by the shoulder.
We’re going!
What did I do?
Nothing, get your sister. We’1l go and buy you some waffles. The two girls race ahead once more.
Don’t be silly. Léa doesn’t answer. They walk along in silence.

Do you think you can erase fifteen years of your life like that? Just by not talking about it? Do you think I was asleep the whole time, like in some kind of fairy tale? Then, one morning, the good fairy Léa came to wake me up? 23. INT. LEA & LUC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Léa is in bed, reading a book. 26 Léa sits on the edge of the bed, listening to the soccer a transistor radio.

Auxerre beat Sochaux 3-2. Lens and Lille drew 2-2 in the big northern derby. Monaco lost to Bordeaux 2-1. Saint-Etienne defeated Marseille 3-0. PSG lost to Nancy at home by 3 goals to 1... Luc Yes! PSG lost! Ha ha! They can stick it up their asses! He flicks off his radio. Luc What are you doing?
Can’t you see? I’m peeling potatoes. Luc Very funny. Jeez, 3-1! (rubs his hands together) Michel’s gonna be in such a bad mood. Luc lies back and gazes at the ceiling. Luc Are the chicklets asleep?
After all the running they did, they were flat out at seven. Luc What about your sister?
What about her? Is she asleep, do you mean? Luc No... What did... I don’t know... Do you talk?
Yes. We talk. Luc Did you ask her...
What? 27  Luc You know... Why? Why she did it?
(wide-eyed) What the hell is wrong with you? Luc Well, what do you talk about then?
Sister things. Luc You’re shitting me!

What do you expect me to say? It all takes time. It’s not easy. My parents banished any thought of my sister from my head. Now, I’ve got her back. It’s like a re-birth. What happened before is... Oh, just let me sleep! She puts her book down, turns off her light and rolls ove

Desserts has been served. Around the table are Léa, Luc, Papy Paul, Michel, Juliett another couple - Samir and his younger, pregnant wife, Ka Through the partition doors, we see Little Lili and Emeli on the couches, fully dressed. At table, the atmosphere is upbeat with all the guests la joking happily. Sitting next to Michel, Juliette seems quite relaxed, too still a little reserved. Just like Luc, who occasionally glances apprehensively at The conversation opens 0.S., the time it takes for the ca track past the two kids into the dining room.

And you know your father backs me 100% on this one. Don’t you, Papy Paul? Luc (0.S.) You must be joking! Dad’s the most loyal supporter Nancy have ever had. Aren’t you, Dad? He reaches for the salad bowl. 28  Léa nods.
Watch out! I glued it back together but I’m not promising anything.
Katrina?
Michel, it’s outrageous that you’ve lived in Lorraine for years and you still support a team that’s mostly made up of Brazilians.
Mostly? Only two Brazilians play for PSG! You don’t know what you’re talking about! Anyway, you’1l bore Juliette!
Unlikely! I love football. I played a lot when I was a teenager.
Seriously?
You were too small to remember.
The perfect woman! Beautiful, intelligent and loves football.
Except for the supporters.
Take that!
Please, Samir, I won’t let an Afghan surgeon paid by al-Qaida to run amok in French hospitals beat me in an argument about football. Luc Can you play on Sunday?
Forget it. He was saying earlier that he has a zillion exams to mark.
29  That’s the third week running you’ve bailed on us.
Yeah, it’s been three weeks that two hundred papers have been sitting on my desk, waiting for me to mark them.
You play football together? The camera closes in on Michel and Juliette. OS, the buzz of the others’ conversation. Juliette nods.
We try. Some days, there’s only ten of us and some days forty people turn up to play, which gets a bit crazy. You should come watch us one day.
Why not.
Do you like it here?
Léa said you lived down south for a long time.
That’s right.
Where?
Carcassonne.
Right, it’s pretty down there. The Black Mountain and all that. Toulouse not far away...
Do you come from Paris?

Yes, but I got bored of it. I go back as infrequently as possible. Life’s good here. If you can put up with lunkheads like these guys! They smile at each other. 25. INT. LIBRARY, LEA AND LUC’S HOUSE - DAY 30 Juliette quietly enters Papy Paul’s room. He sits in his chair, reading. He looks up and smiles at Juliette.
Can I sit with you a while? She sits in the chair opposite him. Papy Paul goes back to his book. Beat. Juliette begins to talk. Papy Paul smiles at her.

Where I was until recently, I always kept a few books near my pillow. I sensed their presence at night when I turned over. It reassured me. She leans forward to see the title of the book he’s readi by Nerval.
I read and re-read that one. Not so much as a means of escape but like a dream. 26. INT. INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Juliette is sitting opposite the Inspector as in the prev scene.

During the week, I eat canned food mostly - lentils and sausages or beef stew. Those are my favourites. I eat in front of the TV onSometimes, I don’t even heat them up. I can’t cook to save my life and I can’t be bothered to learn. I have some green vegetables at the weekend. Doctor’s orders. Do you agree with him?
Definitely. You can’t just eat tinned food.
I guess... What about eggs?
They’re okay, but not every day.
No, I usually boil or fry one up ona Sunday and eat it in front of the Tv. Do you watch TV? 31
No.
Not even when you were in prison?
No.
